Dear Mr. Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the previous corrective
action plan was unsuccessful.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
Resident A attempted suicide by tying a t-shirt around his neck and the doorknob
inside of his room. Resident A was on suicide precautions and staff had been
checking on him every 15 minutes.
2

INVESTIGATION:
Therapist was interviewed at the facility on July 29, 2020. He reported he has been
assigned Resident A’s therapist since he was admitted to Wedgwood. Therapist
stated Resident A was diagnosed with depression and anxiety. Resident A did have
a safety plan that addressed his physical boundaries with others, but no safety plan
regarding suicide ideation or self-harming behavior as Resident A had not displayed
any of these behaviors since admission, until July 20, 2020. He could not recall if
Resident A had a history of self-harming behavior or suicide ideation prior to
admission.
 On July 20, 2020 Therapist was contacted by staff reporting Resident A had
self-harmed by making superficial cuts on his wrist. Therapist met with
Resident A and placed him on High Risk Precaution as Resident A told
Therapist his intention was to kill himself. Therapist reported High Risk
Precaution requires staff to have eyes on Resident A during waking hours and
document his movements throughout the day. T
 On July 21, 2020 Therapist met with Resident A to follow up, along with having
a meeting with his caseworker to discuss supports for Resident A. Therapist
thought Resident A was anxious as he is turning 18 years old and does not
have a support system. Therapist moved Resident A from High Risk to At Risk
Precaution after meeting with Resident A on Tuesday. Therapist reported
Resident A was in a “good space”, smiling, interacting with peers and Resident
A reported feeling okay. Therapist stated Resident A did appear fatigued.
Therapist felt this move was beneficial to Resident A as staff would still be
keeping a close eye on Resident A, documenting his mood and behavior every
15 minutes but would also allow Resident A more opportunities to participate
in activities with peers.
 On July 22, 2020 Therapist stated Resident A slept in but was in the milieu
and interacting with his peers with no concerns. Therapist placed Resident A
on Observation Precaution which requires the same staff supervision of
documenting his mood and behavior every 15 minutes, but would allow
Resident A even more opportunities to participate with peers. Therapist
thought this would assist in increasing Resident A’s mood and reduce his
anxiety. Therapist stated he was contacted by staff notifying him that Resident
A had attempted to commit suicide.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on July 29, 2020. Staff 1 reported she has
worked in the house with Resident A since his admission. Staff 1 recalled Resident
A had a history prior to admission of suicide ideation but he had not acted upon it to
her knowledge. Since Resident A’s admission he had no suicide ideation or self-
harming behavior until Monday July 20, 2020.
 Staff 1 reported after Resident A self-harmed on July 20, 2020 he was placed
on High Risk Precaution. Staff 1 stated when residents are placed on High
Risk, staff are to physically see the resident every 15 minutes or less and
document the resident’s mood, behavior, and actions. All sharp items were
3

removed from Resident A and his bedroom following his self-harming
behavior.
 Staff 1 reported the Therapist originally moved Resident A to Observation
Precaution on Tuesday, however Staff 2 spoke with the Therapist informing
him he cannot miss At Risk Precaution as it should be a progression.
Therapist then placed Resident A on At Risk Precaution. Staff are to continue
to supervise Resident A and document his mood every 15 minutes are less.
 On Wednesday, Staff 1 reported she was working from 7:30am-5:30pm and
at no point did the Therapist check on Resident A. Resident A was self-
isolating himself in his bedroom and sleeping most of the morning. Resident A
came out of his bedroom at lunch time and ate with the group and was
interacting with his peers and staff. Staff 1 stated after lunch Resident A
returned to his bedroom. Staff 1 reported she asked Staff 2 if they had
checked on Resident A, knowing he was to be checked on due to his
Observation Status. Staff 2 replied she had last checked on him at 1:38pm
but would check on him again. Staff 1 looked at her watch and it said
1:44pm. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 yelled for her help and requested a knife as
she had found Resident A in his bedroom with a shirt tied around his neck
and doorknob. Staff 1 noted that the bed appeared to have been made to
looked as if a person was under the covers with the pillows. Staff 1 reported
nursing, management and 911 were contacted.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on August 5, 2020. She stated Resident A had
no history of self-harm since he was admitted to Wedgwood.
 On July 20, 2020 he informed staff he cut his wrist and was placed on High
Risk Precaution by the therapist. Staff 2 informed Resident A of this
precaution and informed him he could not participate in kids club that
evening. High Risk Precaution requires staff to check and document on the
resident in varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes during waking hours
while actively trying to keep the resident engaged with staff and peers
 On July 21, 2020 Therapist moved Resident A from High Risk Precaution to
Observation Precaution. Staff 2 did not agree with this, as she indicated
Resident A complained he could not participate with his peers. Staff 2 stated
she argued this with Therapist, until Resident A was placed on At Risk
Precaution. At Risk Precaution requires staff to check and document on the
resident in varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes during waking hours
and allows resident to participate in staff supervised activities.
 On July 22, 2020 Therapist placed Resident A on Observation Precaution.
Staff 2 was not in agreement with this as Resident A was sleeping all day and
Therapist had not interacted at all with Resident A to determine his mindset.
Observation Precaution requires staff to check and document on the resident
in varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes when the resident is outside
staff’s direct line of sight. Staff 2 reported around lunch time, Resident A
came out of his bedroom from sleeping, completed chores and took a shower
after being directed by staff and then ate lunch. Following lunch, he returned
to his bedroom. Staff 2 stated she checked on Resident A at 1:38pm and
4

observed him in his bedroom sitting at this desk listening to music. Staff 2
walked toward the staff office, and Staff 1 had asked Staff 2 if she had made
a check on Resident A. Staff 2 indicated she had, but would check on him
again before she started paperwork. Staff 2 reported she went to Resident
A’s bedroom at 1:44pm where she found Resident A unresponsive, with a t-
shirt tied around his neck and his bedroom doorknob. Staff 2 noted that the
bed appeared to have been made to look as if a person was under the covers
with the pillows. Staff 2 removed the t-shirt, began CPR and nursing,
management and 911 were contacted.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on August 10, 2020.
 On Monday July 20, 2020 Resident A cut this wrist. Staff 3 reported on
Monday the Therapist placed Resident A on High Risk Precaution where
staff are to have him in line of sight at all times and he is not allowed to
participate in activities.
 On Tuesday he was upset he could not participate in all activities but was
engaged and interacted with peers and staff. On Tuesday, Therapist
placed him on At Risk Precaution where staff are to supervise him when
out of sight documenting every fifteen minutes
 On Wednesday, he slept all morning and came out of his room to do
chores and eat. Staff 3 was outside when Resident A attempted suicide.
Resident A was interviewed via telephone on August 14, 2020. He reported staff
were checking on in often throughout the day on Wednesday, reporting he thought
every 10 minutes or so. He stated he just decided to commit suicide and tied a shirt
around his neck and door.
I reviewed the Suicide Precaution Report which shows that Resident A was placed
on High Risk Precaution on July 20, 2020 at 10am, Observation Precaution on July
21, 2020 at 10am, which was then changed to At Risk, and on Observation
Precaution on July 22, 2020 at 10am.
I reviewed the Close Observation Documentation which documents Resident A
placed on Observation Status on July 21, 2020 at 10:05am. The forms document
Resident A was in his bedroom sleeping, reading, or listening to music for all three
days. He came out to eat meals, attend house meetings or use the bathroom and
then would return to his room. On July 22, 2020 Resident A was documented to be
sleeping in his bedroom until 12:30pm. He was documented to be eating lunch in
the milieu at 12:40pm and then checked on at 1:38pm listening to music in his
bedroom. At 1:44pm Resident A was found by staff unresponsive with a t-shirt tied
around his neck and his bedroom door. In review of the documentation there were 8
times staff exceeded checks of 15 minutes ranging from checks completed at 16
minutes to three hours and thirty-five minutes from the last check.
I reviewed Resident A’s case file. Resident A’s intake summary, client assessment,
residential service plans, psychiatric evaluation, and therapy progress notes,
5

indicate that Resident A had one incident of suicide ideation prior to his admission at
Wedgwood. Resident A admitted to self-harm in the form of cutting when he was 11,
but nothing since that time, until July 20, 2020.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval
checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
ANALYSIS: Although staff performed appropriate checks on Resident A
during the time of the incident, the facility is found in non-
compliance as there were 8 times staff exceeded 15 minutes
while supervising Resident A ranging from checks completed at
16 minutes to three hours and thirty-five minutes from the last
check.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
The Precaution Matrix documents the following staff supervision requirements based
on the precaution level.
 High Risk: At this level, resident must be within sight of staff at all times
during waking hours, remove any items from room that could inflict harm,
and checks/observation are to be documented no less often than every 15
minutes during wake and sleeping hours.
 At Risk: At this level, when resident is not in direct supervision of staff,
checks will be made and documented no less often than every 15
minutes, and staff are to observe resident closely and interact with them
 Observation: At this level, when resident is not in direct supervision of
staff, checks will be made and documented no less often than every 15
minutes.
During interviews with Therapist, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 they reported different
understanding of the supervision and documentation process for residents while
placed on different precaution levels.
I reviewed employee records for the Therapist, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3.
Therapist and Staff 1 did not document any training regarding suicide prevention or
precautions. Staff 2’s training log documented participation in Adolescent Suicide
6

Prevention on 10/12/17 and 2/6/20. Staff 3’s training log documented participation in
Adolescent Suicide Prevention on11/30/17. Staff 2 had noted two disciplinary
actions regarding supervision of residents in 2014 and 2018. Therapist, Staff 1, and
Staff 3 lacked any disciplinary action pertaining to supervision of residents.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in non-compliance as staff did not have a
clear understanding of the precaution levels, processes and the
facility did not have documentation of staff receiving training of
the precaution levels.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency was provided technical assistance to review the
Precaution Matrix thoroughly and make changes based on best
practice to the supervision, documentation, and activities for
residents. It is counterintuitive to restrict a resident from
activities, outings, and visits with support persons when they are
depressed.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SI 2019C0112015 dated 3/28/19, CAP approval date 4/19/19
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended, upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, no changes
be made to the status of the license of this child caring institution.
